choices.text: Both of the conversions will be affected
There will be no affect on conversions

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is suffering from chronic renal failure. Which of the following conversion will be decreased?
questions.solution:
Option B: The conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol is mediated by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase, located in the kidneys.

  • In chronic renal failure (CRF), there is a deficiency of the 1α-hydroxylase enzyme, leading to decreased formation of the active form of vitamin D.

Why Not Others :

Option A: Cholecalciferol to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol: This conversion occurs primarily in the liver and is not significantly affected by renal function.

Option C: Both of the conversions will be affected: Only the conversion to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol is affected by renal failure.

Option D: There will be no effect on conversions: This is incorrect, as the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol is significantly impaired in chronic renal failure.


Key takeaways:

In chronic renal failure, the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol is decreased due to the deficiency of the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase in the kidneys.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is suffering from respiratory alkalosis due to hypoxemia. Which of the following will not be seen in the condition of respiratory alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Respiratory alkalosis does not cause hypercalcaemia; it typically leads to hypocalcaemia. As blood pH rises, more calcium ions bind to plasma proteins, particularly albumin. The increased binding leads to a decrease in the level of ionized (free) calcium in the blood.

  • Tetany occurs when blood calcium levels drop significantly, from a normal of 4 mg/dl to about 6 mg/dl.
  • Lethality is around 4 mg/dl calcium concentration.
  • Hyperexcitability and frequent opening of Na+ channels can occur in respiratory alkalosis.
  • Why Not Others:
  • Option A: can lead to this, contributing to symptoms like tetany.
  • Option B: Hyperexcitability and frequent opening of Na+ channels can occur in respiratory alkalosis.
  • Option D: Hyperexcitability: Commonly seen in respiratory alkalosis due to decreased ionized calcium levels.

Key takeaways:

Hypercalcemia will not be seen in respiratory alkalosis; instead, respiratory alkalosis typically causes hypocalcemia, which can lead to tetany and hyperexcitability.

questions.text: In a patient when sphygmomanometer cuff was inflated greater than the systolic blood pressure and hold for 3 minutes there was involuntary contraction of the muscles of the hand and wrist in the patient. Which of the following sign is positive?
questions.solution:
Positive Trousseau's Sign: Indicates Hypocalcemia.

  • Mechanism: Induction of carpopedal spasm occurs when the cuff is inflated above systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes.
  • Carpopedal Spasm Characteristics:
    • Adduction of the thumb
    • Flexion of metacarpophalangeal joints
    • Extension of interphalangeal joints
    • Flexion of the wrist

Why Not Others:

Option A: Chvostek's sign: Facial muscle spasm upon tapping the facial nerve; also indicates hypocalcemia but is not related to the cuff inflation.

Option C: Kernig's sign: Indicates meningeal irritation; not related to calcium levels. The patient lies on their back with their hips and knees flexed, and the examiner passively extends the patient's leg. The test is positive if the patient experiences pain or resists extending their leg.

Option D: Bruzdinski's sign: Also indicates meningeal irritation; unrelated to hypocalcemia. The patient lies on their back, and the examiner passively flexes the patient's neck. The test is positive if the patient involuntarily flexes their hips and knees.

Key takeaways:

Positive Trousseau's sign, indicating hypocalcemia, is characterized by involuntary contraction of the hand and wrist muscles when the sphygmomanometer cuff is inflated above systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes.

questions.text: A 65-year- old man was suffering from hypercalcemia due to malignancy. He was prescribed a monoclonal antibody 'Denosumab'. Which of the following statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Option C: Denosumab: A monoclonal antibody targeting RANK ligand.

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Inhibits binding of RANKL to RANK receptors on osteoclasts.
    • Effects:
      • Inhibits osteoclast activation.
      • Promotes apoptosis of osteoclasts.

Why Not Others:

Option A: Decreases bone formation: Denosumab primarily inhibits bone resorption, not formation.

Option B: Activation of osteoclast: Denosumab inhibits osteoclast activity, not activates it.

Option D: Increases bone resorption: It decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts.


Key takeaways:

Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits osteoclast activity by blocking RANKL, reducing bone resorption and promoting osteoclast apoptosis.

choices.text: High level of calcium in the blood

questions.text: A 35-year-old female was undergoing thyroid surgery. There occur accidental injury of the parathyroid gland during the thyroid surgery. Which of the following will not be seen?
questions.solution:
Option D: High Level of Calcium in the Blood: This is incorrect; injury to parathyroid glands causes low calcium levels, not high.

  • Accidental Injury to Parathyroid Gland: Results in parathyroid deficiency, leading to hypoparathyroidism.
  • Consequences of Injury:
    • Low Calcium Levels (Hypocalcemia): Due to impaired parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion.
    • Symptoms:
      • Tetany: Involuntary muscle contractions and spasms.
      • Trousseau's Sign: Positive when inducing carpopedal spasm in hypocalcemia.
      • Chvostek's Sign: Facial muscle spasm upon tapping the facial nerve; indicative of low calcium levels.
    • High Phosphate Levels: Due to reduced calcium leading to decreased renal excretion.

Why Not Others:

Option A: Trousseau's Sign: Elicited in hypocalcemia; reflects low calcium levels.

Option B: Tetany: Common clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia after parathyroid injury.

Option C: Chvostek's Sign: Indicates hypocalcemia; positive in cases of parathyroid damage.

Key takeaways:

Injury to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery leads to a decrease in PTH secretion, resulting in hypocalcemia. This condition is characterized by tetany, Trousseau's sign, and Chvostek's sign, while high calcium levels will not be observed.

choices.text: 1, 25 Di OH Vitamin D level

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to orthopaedic department having clinical manifestations like softening of skull, costochondral junction swelling, and pigeon chest. A probable diagnosis of Rickets was made. Most specific test for diagnosis of Vitamin D deficiency is?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rickets: Commonly caused by Vitamin D deficiency, presenting with bone deformities in children.

  • Most Specific Test: 25 OH Vitamin D (Calcidiol) levels provide the most accurate measure of vitamin D status.
    • Reason: Calcidiol reflects overall vitamin D stores in the body.
    • 1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D (Calcitriol): Often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency, hence not reliable for diagnosis.

Why Not Others:

Option A: 1,25 Di OH Vitamin D level: Can remain normal even in severe deficiency, making it less specific.

Option B: 1-alpha hydroxylase level: Reflects enzyme activity related to vitamin D metabolism but is not used for diagnosing deficiency.

Option C: Osteoprotegerin levels: Related to bone remodelling, not specific to vitamin D deficiency.

Key takeaways:

Rickets is commonly caused by vitamin D deficiency, and the most specific test for diagnosis is measuring 25 OH Vitamin D levels.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office due to a 4-month history of headaches and blurred vision. She takes no medications and has no other medical conditions. After the initial laboratory work-up, a CT scan of the abdomen is performed that reveals a 2-cm left-sided adrenal mass. The patient undergoes an uncomplicated left-sided adrenalectomy. Gross examination of the adrenal gland demonstrates a well-defined yellowish tumor within the cortex. Further evaluation reveals that the tumor cells are functionally similar to cells from the outermost hormone-producing layer of the adrenal cortex.
This patient would most likely have had which of the following additional symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Primary Hyperaldosteronism:(CONN~
    • The well-defined yellowish tumor in the adrenal cortex suggests excess aldosterone production, characteristic of primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • Symptoms Related to Hyperaldosteronism:
    • High sodium levels lead to hypertension.
    • Low potassium levels cause muscle weakness and paresthesia.
    • Additionally, metabolic alkalosis may occur due to hydrogen ion loss.

Why not other options:

  • Excessive hair growth:
    • Incorrect: This symptom is associated with excess androgen production, not aldosterone.
  • Weight gain and bruising:
    • Incorrect: These symptoms are indicative of Cushing's syndrome, which involves excess cortisol, not aldosterone.
  • Diarrhea and flushing:
    • Incorrect: These symptoms are more typical of carcinoid syndrome, which is unrelated to aldosterone excess.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's symptoms of muscle weakness and paresthesia are consistent with hyperaldosteronism due to low potassium levels.
  • Identifying the correct hormonal dysfunction is essential for understanding the clinical presentation and management of adrenal tumors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, and increased facial hair over the past year. On examination, she has hypertension, a rounded face, and abdominal striae. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum cortisol levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cushing's Syndrome:
    • Caused by prolonged exposure to high cortisol levels.
    • Common causes include pituitary adenomas (Cushing's disease), adrenal tumors, or ectopic ACTH production.
    • Classic Symptoms:
      • Fatigue and weight gain.
      • Hypertension and rounded face (moon facies).
      • Abdominal striae are also common.

Why not other options:

  • Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease):
    • Incorrect. Characterized by low cortisol, leading to fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure, which do not match this patient's profile.
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome):
    • Incorrect. Excess aldosterone leads to hypertension and hypokalemia, but the weight gain and other symptoms do not typically align with this condition.
  • Pheochromocytoma:
    • Incorrect. This adrenal medulla tumor secretes catecholamines, causing episodic hypertension, palpitations, and sweating, which are not present in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, hypertension, rounded face, and abdominal striae are characteristic of Cushing's syndrome due to elevated cortisol levels.
  • Understanding the clinical features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of adrenal disorders.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. He reports having experienced increased pigmentation of his skin over the past few months, particularly in the creases of his hands and around his mouth. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and laboratory tests show low serum cortisol and high ACTH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Primary Adrenal Insufficiency (Addison's Disease):
    • Characteristics: Inadequate cortisol production due to damage to the adrenal glands.
    • Symptoms:
      • Severe fatigue, weight loss, and hypotension(low blood pressure).
      • Hyperpigmentation due to elevated ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes, especially in skin creases.
    • The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings perfectly align with Addison's disease.

Why not other options:

  • Cushing's Disease:
    • Incorrect. Characterized by excessive cortisol production, typically leading to weight gain, hypertension, and specific facial features. The patient's low cortisol, weight loss, and hypotension are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
  • Secondary Adrenal Insufficiency:
    • Incorrect. This occurs due to insufficient ACTH from the pituitary gland, leading to low cortisol levels. However, it usually does not cause hyperpigmentation since ACTH levels are low; the patient has high ACTH levels, making this diagnosis unlikely.
  • Pheochromocytoma:
    • Incorrect. This adrenal medulla tumor secretes catecholamines, causing episodic hypertension, palpitations, and anxiety, which are not present here. The patient's symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation do not align with pheochromocytoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, hypotension, and hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH levels strongly indicate Addison's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodes of palpitations, severe headache, and sweating that occur intermittently, particularly when she is under stress. She reports feeling anxious during these episodes. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg) and tachycardia. A 24-hour urinary collection shows elevated levels of catecholamines and their metabolites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pheochromocytoma:
    • Characteristics: Tumor of the adrenal medulla secreting catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine).
    • Symptoms:
      • Episodic palpitations, severe headache, sweating, and anxiety during episodes, particularly under stress.
      • Hypertension and tachycardia upon examination.
      • Laboratory Findings: Elevated catecholamines and metabolites in 24-hour urine collection confirm the diagnosis.
    • The combination of episodic symptoms and elevated catecholamines is classic for pheochromocytoma.

Why not other options:

  • Primary Hyperaldosteronism (Conn's Syndrome):
    • Incorrect. This condition involves excessive aldosterone leading to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but does not cause episodic symptoms like palpitations, sweating, or anxiety, nor does it significantly increase catecholamines.
  • Cushing's Syndrome:
    • Incorrect. Characterized by elevated cortisol leading to persistent symptoms like weight gain, hypertension, and fat redistribution. Symptoms are typically not episodic, and the patient's presentation does not match.
  • Secondary Hypertension:
    • Incorrect. Refers to hypertension caused by identifiable conditions. While the patient has hypertension, the episodic nature of symptoms and significant catecholamine levels suggest a specific disorder rather than a generic cause of secondary hypertension, which would not typically involve anxiety or sweating episodes.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's episodic symptoms(palpitations, headaches, sweating) alongside elevated catecholamines confirm a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.
  • Understanding the relationship between symptom patterns and hormone levels is crucial for accurate diagnosis in adrenal gland disorders.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodes of palpitations, severe headache, and sweating that occur intermittently, particularly when she is under stress. She reports feeling anxious during these episodes. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg) and tachycardia. A 24-hour urinary collection shows elevated levels of catecholamines and their metabolites. This hormone is producing by which layer?
questions.solution:
• Pheochromocytoma:
    • Nature: A tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes catecholamines(epinephrine and norepinephrine).
    • Symptoms: Causes episodicsymptoms like palpitations, severe headaches, sweating, and anxiety.
    • Laboratory Findings: Elevated levels of catecholamines confirmed by the 24-hour urine collection.
  • Adrenal Gland Layers:
    • Layer A: Zona Glomerulosa → secretes aldosterone(regulates sodium and potassium).
    • Layer B: Zona Fasciculata → secretes cortisol(stress hormone, regulates metabolism).
    • Layer C: Zona Reticularis → secretes sex hormones(androgens).
    • Layer D: Adrenal Medulla → secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are increased in pheochromocytoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • The catecholamines are produced by the adrenal medulla(Layer D), correlating with the symptoms of pheochromocytoma.
  • Understanding the specific hormones secreted by each layer of the adrenal gland aids in diagnosing related disorders.

questions.text: A male patient of age 35 years presented with complaints of weakness, weight gain, polydipsia, polyuria and low mental health. On physical examination patient is found with moon face, purple striae over the abdomen. In addition, there is blackening of skin due to pigmentation and presence of osteoporosis. Blood tests show cortisol levels in plasma is 5.4 µg/dl. In addition, corticotropin stimulation test shows rise in ACTH level. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: ACTH Dependent Cushing Syndrome

  • Symptoms: Weakness, weight gain, polydipsia, polyuria, low mental health; physical exam shows moon face, purple striae, skin pigmentation, osteoporosis.
  • Lab Findings: Plasma cortisol level at 4 µg/dL; ACTH levels rise after corticotropin stimulation test.
  • Key Points:
    • Cushing Syndrome features: Truncal obesity, muscle weakness, CNS effects from glucocorticoids.
    • ACTH Dependent: Increased ACTH after stimulation indicates pituitary or ectopic ACTH production.

Other Options:

Option B: ACTH Independent: No ACTH change with CRH stimulation.

Option C: Adrenogenital Syndrome: Involves excess androgens, not cortisol.

Option D:Addison's Disease: Characterized by low cortisol, not high.

Key takeaways:

ACTH Dependent Cushing Syndrome due to symptoms of Cushing's (moon face, purple striae) and elevated ACTH after stimulation test.

questions.text: In response to a large mixed meal, the number of glucose transporters in the plasma membrane increases most markedly in which one of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Option A: Insulin-Sensitive GLUT-4: Adipose tissue and muscle contain GLUT-4 transporters, which are insulin-responsive.

  • Postprandial Glucose Clearance: GLUT-4 is crucial for clearing glucose after meals.
  • Mechanism: In adipose and muscle cells, GLUT-4 is stored in vesicles that translocate to the plasma membrane in response to insulin, enhancing glucose uptake.

Why not other options :

Option B: Hepatocyte: While hepatocytes do utilize glucose, they primarily regulate glucose through gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis rather than significantly increasing glucose transporter numbers in response to meals.

Option C: Intestinal Epithelial Cell: These cells use SGLT1 for glucose absorption from the gut but do not significantly increase glucose transporters in response to a mixed meal like GLUT4 in adipocytes.

Option D: Red Blood Cell: Red blood cells rely on GLUT1 for glucose transport, but they do not significantly increase transporter numbers in response to meals, as they continuously take up glucose.

Key takeaways:

In response to a large mixed meal, the number of glucose transporters in the plasma membrane increases most markedly in adipocytes, due to insulin-sensitive GLUT-4 transporters facilitating postprandial glucose clearance. GLUT4 transporters also present in heart and skeletal muscle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has hyperglycemia (160 mg/dL, or 8.9 mM). Immune assays show that the patient has extreme hyperinsulinemia. When injected with a dose of a recombinant human insulin analog that induces mild hypoglycemia in insulin-sensitive persons, this patient develops a similar mild hypoglycemia. This patient most likely has an inborn abnormality of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mutant Insulin: The patient likely has a form of insulin that has normal immunoreactivity but reduced biological activity due to differences in the receptor-binding region.

  • Hyperinsulinemia: Despite high insulin levels, the ineffective insulin results in hyperglycemia.
  • Response to Insulin Analog: The mild hypoglycemia after insulin injection indicates that the insulin is somewhat functional, but not effectively lowering blood glucose levels, pointing to an abnormality in the insulin molecule itself.

Why not other options :

Option A: Glucose Transporter: Abnormalities in glucose transporters typically lead to impaired glucose uptake and would not explain extreme hyperinsulinemia with similar hypoglycemic response.

Option B: Insulin Receptor: An abnormal insulin receptor would generally lead to insulin resistance, not hyperinsulinemia, as the body would produce more insulin in response to high blood sugar.

Option D: Phosphatidylinositol 3-Kinase: This pathway is involved in insulin signaling but would not cause hyperinsulinemia; rather, it would affect the cellular response to insulin.

Key takeaways:

A patient with hyperglycemia and extreme hyperinsulinemia likely has an inborn abnormality of insulin, where a mutant form may have normal immunoreactivity but diminished biological activity, affecting glucose regulation.

choices.text: Determining the presence of islet cell antibodies
Noncontrast CT scan of the abdomen
Blood glucose and insulin levels measured while he was symptomatic

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient received a medical discharge from the Indian Army. He has had multiple episodes of light headedness, sweating, fatigue, tremor, and intense hunger. He had one seizure. During two of these episodes, his blood glucose was 40 mg/dL. Which of the following tests could help you diagnose his problem?
questions.solution:
Option D: Insulinoma Suspected: The patient's symptoms and episodes of hypoglycemia suggest an insulinoma, a tumor that secretes insulin.

  • Blood Glucose and Insulin Levels: Measuring glucose and insulin levels during symptoms will confirm inappropriate insulin secretion, leading to hypoglycemia.
  • Mechanism: The excess insulin drives glucose into peripheral tissues and inhibits hepatic glucose production, causing hypoglycemia and associated symptoms.

Why not other options:

Option A: Determining the Presence of Islet Cell Antibodies: This is more relevant for diagnosing autoimmune type 1 diabetes rather than insulinoma or hypoglycemic episodes.

Option B: HbA1c: This test measures average blood glucose over the past 2-3 months and is not useful for diagnosing acute hypoglycemic episodes.

Option C: Noncontrast CT Scan of the Abdomen: While this could visualize an insulinoma, it wouldn't provide immediate information about insulin levels during hypoglycemic episodes, which is critical for diagnosis.

Key takeaways:

To diagnose the problem in the patient with episodes of hypoglycemia, the most helpful test would be blood glucose and insulin levels measured while he was symptomatic, which can indicate inappropriate insulin secretion likely due to an insulinoma.

choices.text: Insulin therapy is not always necessary
Mostly there is no association with obesity

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician by his mother, mother tells that the child is not well. Over the past few weeks, his mother has noticed that her son has been losing weight even though there is an increase in his appetite and thirst. The patient also passes large volume of urine. On investigation, fasting blood sugar is 250 mg% with urine test positive for glucose. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
Option A:Type 1 diabetes is characterized by insulin deficiency due to autoimmune destruction of the beta cells in the pancreatic islets.

  • Symptoms include:
    • Polyuria(increased urination)
    • Polydipsia(excessive thirst)
    • Weight loss despite polyphagia (increased appetite).
  • Management involves the provision of exogenous insulin as the primary treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Glucose intolerance is severe: True, because Type 1 diabetes causes significant hyperglycemia due to insulin deficiency.

Option C: Autoantibodies are frequently involved: True, as Type 1 diabetes is autoimmune, with antibodies against pancreatic beta cells.

Option D: Mostly there is no association with obesity: True, Type 1 diabetes typically isn't linked to obesity, unlike Type 2.

Key takeaways:

A child presents with signs of type 1 diabetes, including weight loss, increased appetite, thirst, and polyuria, confirmed by high fasting blood sugar and glucose in urine. Insulin therapy is necessary for managing this condition
